review.title: An Efficient Protocol for Negotiation over Combinatorial Domains with Incomplete Information
review.abstract: We study the problem of agent-based negotiation in combinatorial domains. It is difficult to reach optimal agreements in bilateral or multi-lateral negotiations when the agents' preferences for the possible alternatives are not common knowledge. Self-interested agents often end up negotiating inefficient agreements in such situations. In this paper, we present a protocol for negotiation in combinatorial domains which can lead rational agents to reach optimal agreements under incomplete information setting. Our proposed protocol enables the negotiating agents to identify efficient solutions using distributed search that visits only a small subspace of the whole outcome space. Moreover, the proposed protocol is sufficiently general that it is applicable to most preference representation models in combinatorial domains. We also present results of experiments that demonstrate the feasibility and computational efficiency of our approach.

sections.text: We study the problem of agent-based negotiation in combinatorial areas. It is difficult to achieve optimal agreements in bilateral or multilateral negotiations when the preferences of agents for possible alternatives are not generally known. Self-confident agents often negotiate inefficient agreements in such situations. In this essay, we present a protocol for negotiations in combinatorial areas that can induce rational agents to reach optimal agreements under incomplete information conditions. Our proposed protocol allows negotiating agents to find efficient solutions by means of distributed search, covering only a small portion of the entire outcome area. Moreover, the proposed protocol is so general that it applies to most preference representation models in combinatorial areas.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we propose an efficient distributed negotiation protocol, POANCD, for negotiations in combinatorial areas where the actors do not know each other's preferences and do not wish to disclose their preferences for the possible alternatives during the negotiation process. We have theoretically shown that POANCD leads rational actors to pareto-optimal agreements. We have also experimentally shown the significant reduction in search efforts and the number of dominance queries each participating actor must answer with the proposed protocol. A great advantage of POANCD is its extensibility to multilateral negotiations. We have presented POANCD for bilateral negotiations, but its extension to multilateral negotiations can be done with minor modifications. However, the negotiation scenarios with cyclical or contradictory preferences must be further investigated, as it can give more than one best possible agreement (BPA) of a node in a negotiation tree. Furthermore, the fairness of the outcome of the negotiation is an important aspect of the proposed use of the negotiation future.
